title: 115_hr1957
content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress acknowledges that bullying and harassment in schools can lead to physical and psychological harm, hinder learning, and contribute to high dropout rates and academic underachievement. These behaviors negatively impact students' ability to participate in educational opportunities. Bullying and harassment in schools can lead to physical and psychological harm, hinder learning, and contribute to high dropout rates, increased absenteeism, and academic underachievement. Such behaviors include hitting, name-calling, intimidation, social exclusion, and sending insulting messages through various electronic means. Schools with anti-bullying policies can address these issues effectively. Students are targeted for bullying and harassment based on various factors like race, gender, and sexual orientation. Schools with anti-bullying policies see increased reporting and teacher intervention, reducing the frequency of such incidents. Some students face bullying based on race, gender, or sexual orientation. Relational aggression, a form of psychological bullying, damages relationships and social acceptance. Interventions aim to create a positive school climate. Interventions to address bullying and harassment aim to create a positive and safe school climate, using evidence-based discipline policies like PBIS and restorative practices to prevent students from being pushed out or diverted to the juvenile justice system. According to a poll, 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying in schools. Students, parents, educators, and policymakers are calling for action to address the national crisis of bullying and harassment. The purpose of the Safe Schools Improvement Act is to address bullying and harassment in public elementary and secondary schools by implementing anti-bullying policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act addresses bullying, including cyberbullying, in schools by requiring states receiving grants to establish policies that prevent severe, persistent, or pervasive conduct that limits students' participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires states to establish policies to prevent bullying or harassment that limits a student's participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates educational agencies to have policies prohibiting bullying or harassment based on various factors such as race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires educational agencies to have policies prohibiting bullying based on factors such as race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, or other defining characteristics determined by the State or local educational agency. Annual notice must be provided to students, parents, and educational professionals regarding these policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates educational agencies to have policies against bullying based on various factors. They must provide annual notice describing the prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires educational agencies to have policies against bullying and provide procedures for registering complaints about prohibited conduct, including the designated officials and timelines for resolution. Annual data on incidents related to the prohibited conduct must also be collected. The agency must collect annual data on incidents of prohibited conduct at the school building level and publicly report it. Positive and preventative approaches to school discipline should be encouraged to minimize student removal. The agency must ensure that victims or perpetrators of misconduct remain anonymous and promote positive disciplinary approaches in schools to reduce student removal and avoid disproportionate punishment. State reports are required from the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant under this title, in cooperation with the State educational agency. The report should include information from local educational agencies and describe the State's plans to support efforts in addressing prohibited conduct. The Secretary will conduct a biennial evaluation of programs and policies to combat bullying and harassment in schools, including assessing the effectiveness of the requirements in reducing prohibited conduct and implementing parent involvement programs. The Commissioner for Education Statistics will collect data from States to determine the incidence of prohibited conduct. The Commissioner for Education Statistics will collect data from States to determine the incidence and frequency of conduct prohibited by policies. The Secretary will submit a biennial report to the President and Congress on the evaluation findings and collected data. "SEC. 4705. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS." The text states that federal and state nondiscrimination laws will not be affected by the current part, including laws such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Education Amendments of 1972, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations under this part are additional to those imposed by existing laws. The obligations under this part are in addition to federal and state nondiscrimination laws such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Education Amendments of 1972, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. This part does not affect legal standards or rights related to free speech and expression. The text states that nothing in this part shall affect free speech and expression laws under other federal laws. The text in section 4706 clarifies that states and local entities can still enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with the provisions in this part.
